29.text:
Ladies and gentlemen,
please welcome your favourite
family-friendly entertainer,

35.text:
who would never insult anyone,
and in the current climate
would very much like to keep his job.

57.text:
Welcome to another adorable and
harmless Never Mind The Buzzcocks.

63.text:
This week's guest team captain
is a national treasure

66.text:
and somebody whose family I very
much respect. It's Jack Dee.

75.text:
Their last single was inspired by
lesbians but we won't be dwelling

79.text:
on that filth tonight,
thank you very much.
It's Alphabeat singer, Stine.

88.text:
And she's just hosted Channel
4's Sex Education Show, where

91.text:
I assume the lesson was "not before
marriage and never to be enjoyed".
It's Anna Richardson.

98.text: And on Phill's team this evening...

102.text:
She's the winner of ITV2's wonderful
Celeb Air, who only had a small role

106.text:
in turning the nation into
violent materialistic murderous
hoodies with So Solid Crew.

113.text:
And he's a comedian, writer
and communist.

117.text:
But tonight he has agreed to
tone all of that down for some
traditional, risk-free quiz fun.

122.text:
It's pillar of the
establishment, Alexei Sayle.

126.text:
Those are the teams.
Let's have a respectful round of

129.text:
applause for them and the days when
you could leave your doors unlocked.

137.text:
So we begin with Sorry, No Refunds.
Phill, Alexei and Lisa, watch this.

141.text:
# Oh no so easily you're over me
Gone is love it's me that ought... #

147.text:
Oh, I love the Ting Tings
and their innovative,
avant-garde take on pop music.

151.text:
# "Na na na na na na na, and that
should get in the charts, uh."

159.text:
That was the Ting Tings,
with Shut Up And Let Me Go,

162.text:
but why did they remove a song from
the Chinese release of their album?

165.text:
Was it because A, authorities
feared the indecipherable lyrics
contained an anti-Chinese message?

170.text:
B, it was too similar to the
Taiwanese national anthem?

176.text:
Or C, any more than
eight songs on an album

180.text:
If it was anything like So Solid,
we got banned for absolutely...

184.text: OK, we did do bad things but...

186.text:
you know. When you say "we",
which one of the 920 members

193.text:
No, we was banned from playing
certain shows in certain places.

198.text:
You said So Solid were banned
from this very building earlier.
How did you get in? Oh, yeah.

203.text:
Why? Top Of the Pops days, cos they
were smoking the good stuff.

207.text:
Or, as we call it here at the BBC,
the illegal stuff.

220.text:
Thanks to your pusillanimous
lack of courage, this is
a really shit show, isn't it?

228.text:
We can't push any boundaries,
can we? You know, we can't
say what's on our mind.

233.text:
We've got to be frightened
of offending the powers
that be, you know?

239.text:
All right, I do voiceovers
for banks. But...
LAUGHTER

242.text:
..I'm sneering
when I do them voiceovers.

245.text:
We've all just got to have
a nice pop quiz tonight, OK?

248.text:
There's a question.
What's the answer?

255.text:
Alexei, you used to be a Maoist.
What do you think of the Ting Tings?

258.text:
Oh, yes, I used to be a Maoist.
You're not a real Communist now?

263.text:
Why is that? Didn't work out,
did it, really?

273.text:
So, Lisa! Yeah. Lisa Maffia,
lovely to have you here.

276.text: Nice to see you again, Simon.

277.text:
How does it feel to win Celeb Air?
Fantastic.

280.text:
You were there with Chico and
Johnny Shentall, and Lisa Scott-Lee.

286.text:
And Michelle Marsh. So really,
even if you hadn't won, it's
still an honour to fly with them.

292.text:
No, I'd have been absolutely
gutted if I didn't win,

295.text:
to be honest. OK. Was it like,
"Would you like some nuts,
madam?" "No thanks."

299.text:
"I said, do you want some nuts?!
Do you want some nuts?!"

304.text:
It was more like,
"Who are you talking to?"

324.text:
That's the thing with a funny
costume. It works at first. Yeah.

328.text:
And then... I saw Rik Mayall in
about 1980, came on in a bunny suit.

332.text:
Oh no! It got a huge laugh. Yeah,
it's been done before. Oh!

337.text:
He got a huge laugh, but then
he was stuck in that outfit
for another 90 minutes.

343.text:
You can't intimidate a heckler
in a bunny suit. Mmm.

353.text:
I don't care, you're still shit.
And you're a shit rabbit.

360.text:
See, you can't
intimidate me, can you? No.

364.text:
OK. A, anti-Chinese messages,
B, too similar to Taiwanese
national anthem,

369.text:
C, unlucky if you have more than
eight songs on an album
in China. What do you think?

373.text:
I think unlucky numbers.
The unlucky numbers.
Is that what you're going for?

377.text: Yeah. OK. You're wrong, I'm afraid.

380.text:
The answer is A, the Chinese
authorities were concerned that
the song Impacilla Carpisung

385.text:
sung might have contained subliminal
anti-Chinese messages, because it is

391.text:
A shocked Dalai Lama said,
"Not track nine! This must be the
worst thing China's ever done!"

397.text:
OK. Jack, Stine and Anna,
look at this.

400.text:
# I know it's gone and
there's gonna be violence... #

405.text:
"Hello, Mr Travel Agent,
I'm sick of it, I wanna
get out of the spotlight."

409.text:
"Well, Mr Williams, we can offer
you a remote Pacific island?"

412.text:
"Hmmm, I was thinking more LA.
Isn't that the global capital
of showbusiness? Perfect!"

420.text:
That was Robbie Williams with
Tripping, but why has he been

424.text:
banned from performing
at a Dubai racecourse?

426.text:
Is it A, because he scared the
horses last time he played there?

430.text:
B, he offended the Sheikh with
his position on the Middle East?

433.text:
Or C, something to do
with Ant, but not Dec?

438.text:
Well, he wasn't allowed to
play in Dubai because
the people of Dubai were worried

444.text:
there was a message in his song, and
they thought it was gobbledegook and

448.text:
was going to be offensive to them,
and so they banned him.

451.text:
It's not right, but, had you been
sat there ten minutes ago,
you could have got an point.

457.text:
What about Stine from
Alphabeat being here?

465.text: Welcome to the show. Thank you.

469.text:
That song you've got, Boyfriend,
was inspired by a film about two
lesbians? That's true, yeah.

475.text:
I assume that the film
was about them feeling

478.text:
ashamed of what they'd done and
that they'd never do it again?
Obviously, yes. Good, good.

482.text:
And you're not...a lesbian
yourself, are you?

485.text:
Erm, no. Good, phew!
Did you think so?

489.text:
Well, I was concerned.
We can't have lesbians on the show.

493.text:
Oh good, you're not a... Are
there any lesbians in the audience?

507.text: I don't even want a small one.

511.text: Jack Dee? I'm not a lesbian, no,

514.text: but I can see their point.

523.text:
You did the programme on Channel 4,
the Sex Education Show? Yes.

526.text:
Tell us, what was in it? What did
you find out? What did you discover?

529.text:
I think the most shocking
revelation was that most teenagers

535.text:
have absolutely no idea,
basically, about STIs.

541.text:
When I was a teenager, I
had no ideas about STIs.

543.text:
My God, I do now, but...
LAUGHTER

548.text:
Now, does this sort of thing
need to be in our living rooms?

553.text:
Does it, really? Can you tell me
what the number one STI is, Simon?

559.text:
Have I been checked? Yeah.
As an employee of the BBC, I...

565.text:
..There's no need for me to ever be
checked because I've never had sex.

569.text:
To be honest, in that
outfit I can see why.

571.text:
If this doesn't get me
laid I don't know what will!

578.text:
I liked that bit when you did the
tantric sex thing, didn't you?

582.text:
Was that on top of having my full
Hollywood bikini wax - on camera,

587.text:
and actually
having my arsehole waxed?

594.text: Why did you have your bottom waxed?

596.text:
When you have a bikini
wax, especially if you

598.text:
have it all taken off,
it kind of improves your sex life.

602.text:
And I've never had a bikini wax
in my life, so I was sent off
for one, to see whether in fact

606.text:
this works, and I was only told
when I got there that I was
having the whole lot off.

612.text:
Quite hairy! I've got to tell you.
You haven't got to
tell us that, actually.

619.text: Stop when you feel you want to!

626.text:
One or two complaints, you see,
that's where it all starts,
doesn't it?

630.text:
30,000 by the end of the week,
by the time they've read about it.

634.text:
Lisa, did anybody complain
about Celeb Air...or watch it?

640.text:
Well, anyway, Robbie,
Robbie Williams. Robbie Williams.

644.text:
We got distracted
talking about STIs and actually it's
Robbie we want to talk about.

649.text:
Jack, I thought you'd be grumpy.
You're quite perky. I'm trying
to be. You've cheered me up, Simon.

654.text:
You've spoiled the illusion for me
because I usually am quite grumpy,

658.text:
but when you came on dressed
as a rabbit, I just thought,
life's all right, actually.

668.text:
Really? I assume that is the right
question, yeah. Answer... question?

686.text:
You're saying B. Yes.
He offended the Sheikh with
his position on the Middle East.

693.text:
can I just say, I'm the
team captain, the answer didn't
come from me, it came from Stine.

698.text:
It wasn't the answer that
my team was giving as far as I was
concerned, so it's not legitimate.

703.text:
I think that's fair enough.
This has never happened before.

708.text:
Well, we've never had a
gobby Dane on the show before.

713.text: What would you say the answer is?

718.text:
We think it's A actually, now.
What? This is a travesty!

727.text:
We need to turn the cameras
round so that you are
answering the questions.

762.text:
It's not your job
that's in jeopardy!

768.text:
So what are you going for? You've
gone for B, that's wrong.

771.text:
Out of all of those it's the
only one that makes sense to me.

777.text:
OK, as you're a guest,
you are correct. What about that?

785.text:
the leading Sheikh in Dubai
ruled the singer couldn't

788.text:
play at the racecourse, having
scared the horses before.

790.text:
One of the horses was so
disturbed by the whole incident,

793.text:
he now sits in his stable all day,
smoking and ranting to himself
about Gary Barlow.

799.text:
OK. Next up, it's the mildly
xenophobic Intros Round.

804.text:
Phill and Lisa, here are
yours for Alexei Sayle.

810.text:
OK, so that earlier
incident with Mr D's team...

815.text: that's how we do the quiz now.

818.text: Would you just let it go, come on.

822.text:
Let's just have a
good time tonight, Phill.

We'll just do the introduction to
Freedom by Wham! That will be it.

834.text:
If correct, here's
how it should have sounded.

845.text:
Alexei, if you win
tonight, next series they could
let you be on Celeb Air.

849.text:
Imagine that. Will you stop
taking the piss out of that show?

852.text:
That show was good
and I really enjoyed it.

854.text: Yeah, yeah, we all enjoyed it.

856.text:
Well, I've done really well
and I won over 11 celebrities.

863.text: Yeah. Let's say 11 people, shall we?

868.text:
No, it was a wonderful achievement.
Yeah, it was.

870.text:
Do you feel closer now to the
So Solid Crew or the cabin crew?

876.text: I feel closer to you, Simon.

878.text:
Thank you. Closer to you. That's
very nice. Let's have a song.

902.text:
It's annoying, isn't it?
Isn't it annoying?

910.text: Go for it. I Am The Walrus.

912.text:
It's correct.
Here's how it should have sounded.

916.text:
MUSIC: "I Am The Walrus"
By The Beatles

924.text:
So that was I Am The
Walrus by The Beatles.

926.text:
Ringo Starr recently posted
a YouTube video saying he

928.text:
wouldn't sign any more fan mail

931.text:
Ironically he's now much busier
throwing away parcels
full of dog shit.

943.text: You like that one, do you?

945.text: I did a good one, did a good one.

956.text:
But we can carry on, right?
Yes. OK. Jack and Stina,

959.text:
here are yours
for Anna Richardson from the sex
show, The Sex Education Show.

965.text: She has sex on a show.

968.text:
I honestly have
no clue how to do that one.

970.text: It's great having you on the team(!)

975.text: I know, I do my best.

976.text: Yes, I know. One, two, three, four.

980.text:
Boof boo-dum boom boom boom
Boof boo-dum boom boom...

989.text:
Boof boo-dum boom boom boom
Boof boo-dum boom doh, wooh!

993.text:
I had no
help at all doing that.

997.text:
I counted you in, didn't I?
Yeah, thanks.

There was a bit like
watching my dad at a wedding.

1004.text:
Can you do it again Jack,
because I enjoyed it. Go on.

1007.text:
I'll do it again, shall I? Yeah. Go

1011.text:
Dum boom boom boom
Boom du-boom boom boom boom
Wooh Boom du-boom boom boom

1018.text:
You are getting
better and better, you.

1020.text: Is there any sort of melody to it?

1023.text:
Yes! There is, but... Speak to Stine
about the melody. Stina, come on!

1029.text: Am I the only one making an effort?

1034.text:
The only song with "wooh!
Boom-da boom boom ki" is Spiralling.

1042.text:
It was Spiralling by Keane. Here's
how it should have sounded.

1055.text:
Well, get out of your weird
bunny suit then.

1059.text:
Why don't you get out
of your weird bunny suit.

1061.text:
I'm not wearing a bunny suit.

1066.text: OK, go ahead. Last song. OK.

1070.text:
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding

1075.text:
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding

1080.text:
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding

1085.text:
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding

1089.text:
Ding ding ding ding
Ding ding ding ding Solo.

1098.text:
Is this music being played over
the top of the BBC massive balloon

1106.text:
Is it like a BBC... It's not
Snow Patrol, is it?

1109.text:
Let me just say what a wonderful
balloon that BBC balloon is.

1114.text:
And what about the
British countryside, eh?

1116.text:
I know what it is. I just don't know
the group, if it's not Snow Patrol.

1120.text:
I think you might be right although
I don't know. Do you have any idea?

1127.text: No, it's Hoppipolla by Sigur Ros.

1130.text:
Here's how it
should have sounded.

1134.text:
Is that the one you were thinking
of? Balloon. Oh yeah. Countryside.

1144.text: That was Hoppipolla by Sigur Ros.

1146.text:
The song is often used in TV
montages to make classic iconic
events even more memorable.

1151.text:
For example, who could
forget these amazing scenes?

1169.text:
We also heard Spiralling by Keane.
Keane's new album explores
many difficult issues, such as

1174.text:
the Iraq war, the recession
and the curse of being a thin man
with a chubby toddler's head.

1188.text:
Now we come to a round called
Hello, Is It Me You're Looking For?

1192.text:
Each team is given four famous
people, and they have to guess
the odd one out -

1196.text:
Or, in our clever, twisted idea,
the one you are looking for.

1200.text:
Phill, Lisa and Alexei,
your people are... Eminem,

1209.text:
Which of them is the
one you're looking for?

1211.text: I can give you a clue... Oh, please.

1214.text: The clue is pain and pleasure.

1217.text:
This looks like Tarantino's next
film just arrived. Alexei, are you
a fan of anyone in the line-up?

1223.text:
I loved Eminem, and I wanted to
be his best friend for a while.

1226.text:
I wanted a celebrity friend
and I thought...

1231.text:
I'd like to have a really good
celebrity friend and for a while

1235.text:
I wanted my celebrity friend
to be Eminem.

1237.text:
I thought we'd hang around together
on a motorbike, with me on the back.

1247.text:
Let's not worry about the round,
let's talk to Lisa Mafia a bit more.

1250.text:
Can you be an actual
cabin crew person now?

1254.text:
I've done many other things.
The Games, on Channel 4?

1257.text: Yeah, about four years ago. Yeah!

1261.text:
And I went to number four in the
dance charts, Bad Girl. Bad Girl..

1265.text:
A dance track. House track.
Nobody's saying you haven't...

1269.text:
Well, can you stop banging on about
a show that never got watched?!
LAUGHTER

1274.text: Would you do other shows like that?

1278.text: Only if I could kick arse.

1281.text:
It would be nice. You could
go to Afghanistan with Chico.

1288.text: What time is it? It's wartime.

1292.text:
I got paid really well for that
job, so I really don't give a shit.

1300.text:
Good for you.
The old Danny Dyer excuse.

1304.text:
OK, which one do you
think is the odd one out?

1307.text:
Eminem and, er, thingy and
Springsteen and Angus Young were all

1313.text:
played at high volume to get people
out of an embassy or something.

1317.text:
And Pink was played to - I don't
know - Pink's the odd one out.

1326.text:
Let's see if you're right. Can
the real One You Were Looking For
please step forward?

1331.text: Pink! You are correct. It was Pink.

1336.text:
Her song Family Portrait has been
used in family therapy sessions

1340.text:
whereas all the others have had
their music used by the American
military as a form of torture.

1346.text:
Please, join me in a round
of applause for our stars and
the pleasure they bring.

1355.text:
All right, Jack, Stine and Anna
your people are Kylie Minogue,

1360.text: Dave Grohl, John Lennon and Sting.

1369.text:
But which of them is the odd one
out, or the One You're Looking For?

1372.text: The clue here is the supernatural.

1375.text:
Supernatural? Hmmmm.
I was going to say the guy in black

1379.text:
is the odd one out because
the others have got white on.

1383.text: Yeah, it's going to be that easy.

1385.text:
Which of those do you fancy, Anna,
if you had to have sexual relations?
If I had to have tantric sex?

1391.text:
Dave Grohl's worrying me
because he keeps smiling at me.

1400.text: Really creepy! You're a scary man.

1403.text:
John Lennon looks
more like Rose West!

1410.text:
Kylie's looking quite hot.
What do you think? Definitely.

1416.text: It doesn't have to be lesbianism.

1423.text:
People just didn't like the idea of
you having sex there. Why is that?!

1427.text: Um... Are you a grumpy lover?

1434.text: "OK, then. I hope YOU liked it."

1446.text:
I was picking up on something
Anna was saying.

1449.text: Don't blame it on me if it's wrong.

1452.text: Don't pick up anything from Anna.

1457.text:
Is it David Grohl is
really into UFOs?

1470.text:
And...probably so do
two of the other ones,

1477.text:
You are definitely talking out loud.
OK, thank you for that warning.

1482.text:
I need an answer
from you, I'm afraid.

1487.text:
I think there is something about
John Lennon. I think...being
the only one that's dead,

1491.text:
he's a ghost, haunting people maybe?
I don't know.

1496.text:
I think you should go with Stine.
Oh, well done. Maybe you
should listen to me for once.

1500.text:
I will from now on. It's nice to
hear you do something.

1508.text:
Does he? It was meant... I
don't like you any more. Oh(!)

1512.text: Well, it's near the end of the show.

1518.text:
Is Stine right? Stine's right,
what she said was right.

1521.text: You didn't even hear what I said.

1524.text:
Say it in Danish and
then he can't dispute it.

1535.text:
So you're saying John Lennon
is the odd one out. Yeah.

1539.text:
Let's see if you are right.
There you go! What about that?

1547.text:
So you've got it. They all have been
visited by ghosts, apart from John,

1550.text:
whose ghost is said to have visited
Paul McCartney and Liam Gallagher.
Sting believes

1554.text:
his childhood home was haunted
by Roman centurions,

1557.text:
Dave Grohl thinks his home is
haunted by a native American baby,

1560.text:
and Kylie claims to be visited by
Michael Hutchence, who this evening
it's best not not to dwell on.

1568.text:
Join me in a round of applause
for our stars and the charity
of your choice.

1577.text:
So, we end with Next Lines.
Jack's team, you're in the lead.

1582.text: You go first. Your time begins now.

1590.text: In a Barbie world. Correct. Aqua.

1591.text: The word is on your lips...

1600.text: Get up off of that thing...

1602.text: And dance till you feel better.

1604.text:
Correct. James Brown. Oh! Oh!
END-OF-ROUND-JINGLE

1610.text:
We were really good.
You've got nine points.

1615.text:
How do you feel about that, Jack?
I'm pretty chuffed, Simon.

1618.text: I think it's been good, clean fun,

1621.text:
and we've done very well.
I would be surprised, really,

1625.text: if the other team were to top that.

1627.text:
You've got nine points, you've
got three points. Here we go. OK.

1632.text:
Your time begins now.
I am the walrus...

1636.text:
Correct. The Beatles,
I Am The Walrus. What time is it...

1649.text: Go on, do a little bit.

1652.text: # Hello, John, got a new motor?

1658.text:
# Now I'm just a pathetic
old geezer...

1662.text:
# I've humiliated myself
on a pop quiz and lost all
intellectual credibility... #

1669.text: It made it all worth it.

1673.text: And so to the final scores.

1676.text:
Phill's team have eight points.
Jack's team have nine points.

1687.text:
So, thanks to Phill, Lisa
and Alexei, Jack, Stine and Anna.

1691.text:
This has been Never Mind The
Buzzcocks. I've had a lovely, safe
time, and hope you have too.

1696.text:
But if there's anything at all you
don't like about me, just let me
know and I'll be happy to change.
